attributes.title: Data Files
attributes.description: This is where behavioral data for the project will be shared. For each data file, there should be a corresponding data dictionary.

q1.value: The effect of delay length on time preferences across adulthood

q2.value: Shelby Denise Leverett, Kendra Leigh Seaman, Christopher Garza

q3.value: Many decisions involve considering trade-offs between a smaller sooner option and a larger later option. In these situations, people tend to devalue, or discount, the later option. This devaluation is known as temporal discounting. If the smaller, sooner option occurs now, this is known as delay discounting. If the smaller, sooner option occurs in the future, this is known as intertemporal discounting. The extent to which the later option is discounted varies largely between people, and research has shown mixed age effects. Some studies have found that with age, people discount more steeply, others have found that with age people discount less steeply, and others have not found any evidence that age has an effect on temporal discounting at all.  We posit that one of the reasons for these heterogeneous results is that existing studies have used a mixture of time delays, ranging from days to years. One prominent theory of aging, socioemotional selectivity theory (SST), suggests that older adults become more present-oriented than younger adults because their future is more limited. Because of limited time horizons, older adults view the future as more uncertain, and this uncertainty may lead older adults to discount future rewards more than younger adults. Thus, for older adults, the greater the delay between now and an outcome, the greater their uncertainty about whether they will be alive and able to realize that outcome. This predicts that for longer time delays, older adults will discount more than younger adults. However, for shorter time delays older adults should not show a differences from younger adults. This hypothesis has not been empirically tested. Our goal is to clarify the effect that age has on delay discounting by systematically examining discounting when time delays of vary greatly in terms of magnitude.

q4.value:
H1: We hypothesize that across all ages, we will see greater discounting (or greater proportion of sooner options) with longer time delays.

H2: We hypothesize that this increase in discounting for longer time delays will vary by age. Specifically, we predict that age differences in time preferences will only appear with longer time delays. For shorter time delays (days, weeks, months), there will be no age differences in discount rates. For longer time delays (years), older adults will show greater discounting than younger adults because of uncertainty about their future.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Independent variables: age (between-subjects), discount rate (within-subjects) and time interval (within-subjects)
Dependent variable: proportion of smaller, sooner options chosen
Potential moderators (exploratory analyses): Future Time Perspective, Safety Net and Savings 

Other exploratory analyses: Impact of time label (large number, small unit (e.g. 7 days) vs. small number large unit (e.g. 1 week)

q9.value: The order in which the time delays are presented in the delayed discounting trials is randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants: We will collect data from 276 participants (ages 25-84). The sample will be subdivided into six age categories, or bins (i.e: 25-34, 35-44, 45-54, 55-64. 65-74, 75-84). Each bin will have an equal number of participants (i.e: 46), and an equal number of men and women (i.e: 23). Finally, to build a sample that is representative of the US population, we will recruit participants to match the racial diversity described in the most recent US census (i.e: 75% Caucasian, 13% African-American, 5% Asian, etc).
Participants will be recruited with Qualtrics Panels, a service designed to recruit individuals from pre-existing participant pools, based on the criteria of researchers. Qualtrics Panels compensates the participant with Qualtrics points that can ultimately be redeemed for gift cards. We will include healthy participants between the ages of 25-84 and exclude participants with any psychological or neurological health issues as indicated by our online screening survey. 
      

Procedure: The entirety of the study takes places online through a Qualtrics survey. Participants will first answer a brief screening for our inclusion and exclusion criteria (age, gender, and psychological or neurological health issues). Eligible participants will then be consented. This is followed by the demographic questionnaire for age, ethnicity, income, and subjective health. Next, participants will complete the Future Time Perspective (FTP) survey, a 10-item scale to measure their subjective perception of how much time they feel they have left to live. This will be followed by the delay discounting practice round and task, in which participants choose which option they would prefer when presented with a smaller, sooner and a larger, later option.  Finally, they will be presented with the Savings and Safety Net subscale (from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau) to assess their saving habits and financial security across their lifetime . The total survey duration is estimated to be 7-8 minutes.

q13.value: As indicated by power analyses, we will have a sample size of 276 individuals between the ages of 25 and 85 years old. The sample will be subdivided into six age bins (i.e 25-34 35-44,...75-85) and within each age bin there will be an equal number of participants (i.e 46), and an equal number of men and women (i.e: 23).

q14.value: In order to detect a small effect size (Cohen's d= 0.2) with 80% power, power analyses indicated that we would need a sample size of 275. The sample was rounded to 276 to have an equal number of participants in each of the six bins.

q15.value: Qualtrics Panels will terminate participant recruitment and data collection when we have reached the target sample size, with the target composition of participants in each bin (i.e: equal numbers of men and women).

question.value:
We are manipulating the time delay between the smaller, sooner option and the larger, later option. There are 4 levels of this variable: days, weeks, months, years. Each level has 3 sub-levels: a low-point, a midpoint, and a high-point. To enable investigations into framing effects, the high-point of one level is equivalent to the low-point of the subsequent level (i.e: 12 months and 1 year).

The delay discounting task itself is comprised of 36 task trials, and 3 catch trials which are used as attention checks. We use a combination of 12 time intervals and 3 hypothetical discount rates to create 36 delay discounting trials. We use the following time intervals: 1 day, 4 days, 7 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 4 weeks, 1 month, 6 months, 12 months, 1 year, 5 year, and 10 years. We use the three different discount rates: k= .1, k= .05, and k=.005. In order to estimate an appropriate future amount, corresponding to the three discount rates and the given time delays, we used the following formula: reward=SV * (1+ k*days). In this formula, SV (subjective value) is the dollar amount of the reward today (set to $10 in every trial), reward is the dollar amount in the future after a given time delay, k is the discount rate, and days is the time delay (given in days). We operationalized a month to be 28 days.

The primary outcome variable is the acceptance rate, or the proportion of sooner options chosen in the delay discounting task. We will measure age (in years) as the continuous covariate, and will measure future time perspective, as measured by the FTP scale (Carstensen and Lang, 1996), as a mediator.
- KS: should I add our demographic questions & savings & safety net questions here too?

H1: We hypothesize that across all ages, we will see greater discounting (or greater proportion of sooner options) with longer time delays.

H2: We hypothesize that this increase in discounting for longer time delays will vary by age. Specifically, we predict that age differences in time preferences will only appear with longer time delays. For shorter time delays (days, weeks, months), there will be no age differences in discount rates. For longer time delays (years), older adults will show greater discounting than younger adults because of uncertainty about their future.

We will test these hypotheses by predicting the proportion of sooner options chosen with two models:

First, we will test a 3 (k-values: 0.1, 0.05, 0.005) by 4 (time: days, weeks, months, years) by Age (25-84 years) ANCOVA. 

H1: Main effect of delay with longer delays (years) having greater acceptance of sooner option.
H2: Age * Delay interaction such that age difference only appear for longer delays (years)

Next, we will convert the categorical predictors above into continuous variables. The three k values will be log-transformed (-1, -1.301, -2.301) to reduce skewness and the twelve time delays will be converted into a common scale: number of days (1 day, 4 days, 7 days, 14 days, 28 days, 30 days, 180 days, 365 days, 1825 days, 1650 days). These two continuous predictors (log(k) and delay in days) will be used in a linear model.


H1: Main effect of number of days such that longer delays ( > 365 days) having greater acceptance of the sooner option.
H2: Age * number of days interaction such that age difference only appear for longer delays (>365 days)

q21.value:
We will use two-tailed tests with a p-value of .05 to make inferences. 

When necessary, we will use Bonferroni corrections for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: We will include three catch trials in the delay discounting task where there is an obvious correct answer (unlike the other trials in the delay discounting task). If a participant chooses incorrectly on one of these catch trials, their survey immediately ends and they are escorted out of the session. We will not use the data from participants who are excluded due to catch trials, as we want to ensure that everyone is attending to the task, especially when it is so short. We plan to include all of the rest of the data points from other participants in our analyses.

q23.value: We don't expect to have any missing data. As the survey is being conducted online in Qualtrics, each question has been built to require a response before the participant can move on to the next question.

q24.value:
First, plan to investigate framing effects. We will test frame (large number with small unit vs small number with large unit) and Age on discounting in the relevant subset of trials. 

Second, we are curious about the relationship between future time perspective and discounting. We will test if FTP mediates the relationship between age and discounting, and whether or not this relationship is moderated by time delay.

Finally, we plan to investigate whether discount rates correlate with lifetime saving habits, specifically with the amount of money in liquid savings. If this relationship is found to be significant, we will control for wealth in our analyses.

attributes.title: The effect of delay length on time preferences across adulthood
attributes.description: This project will examine how differential time delays impact delayed discounting across the lifespan. More updates to come.

q1.value: The effect of delay length on time preferences across adulthood

q2.value: Shelby Denise Leverett, Kendra Leigh Seaman, Christopher Garza

Some studies have found that with age, people discount more steeply, others have found that with age people discount less steeply, and others have not found any evidence that age has an effect on temporal discounting at all.  We posit that one of the reasons for these heterogeneous results is that existing studies have used a mixture of time delays, ranging from days to years. One prominent theory of aging, socioemotional selectivity theory (SST), suggests that older adults become more present-oriented than younger adults because their future is more limited. Because of limited time horizons, older adults view the future as more uncertain, and this uncertainty may lead older adults to discount future rewards more than younger adults. Thus, for older adults, the greater the delay between now and an outcome, the greater their uncertainty about whether they will be alive and able to realize that outcome. This predicts that for longer time delays, older adults will discount more than younger adults. However, for shorter time delays older adults should not show a differences from younger adults. This hypothesis has not been empirically tested. Our goal is to clarify the effect that age has on delay discounting by systematically examining discounting when time delays of vary greatly in terms of magnitude.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: We hypothesize that across all ages, we will see greater discounting (or greater proportion of sooner options) with longer time delays.

H2: We hypothesize that this increase in discounting for longer time delays will vary by age. Specifically, we predict that age differences in time preferences will only appear with longer time delays. For shorter time delays (days, weeks, months), there will be no age differences in discount rates. For longer time delays (years), older adults will show greater discounting than younger adults because of uncertainty about their future.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: The order in which the time delays are presented in the delayed discounting trials is randomized.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: As indicated by power analyses, we will have a sample size of 276 individuals between the ages of 25 and 85 years old. The sample will be subdivided into six age bins (i.e 25-34 35-44,...75-85) and within each age bin there will be an equal number of participants (i.e 46), and an equal number of men and women (i.e: 23).
registration_responses.q14: In order to detect a small effect size (Cohen's d= 0.2) with 80% power, power analyses indicated that we would need a sample size of 275. The sample was rounded to 276 to have an equal number of participants in each of the six bins.
registration_responses.q15: Qualtrics Panels will terminate participant recruitment and data collection when we have reached the target sample size, with the target composition of participants in each bin (i.e: equal numbers of men and women).
registration_responses.q21:
We will use two-tailed tests with a p-value of .05 to make inferences. 

When necessary, we will use Bonferroni corrections for multiple comparisons.
registration_responses.q22: We will include three catch trials in the delay discounting task where there is an obvious correct answer (unlike the other trials in the delay discounting task). If a participant chooses incorrectly on one of these catch trials, their survey immediately ends and they are escorted out of the session. We will not use the data from participants who are excluded due to catch trials, as we want to ensure that everyone is attending to the task, especially when it is so short. We plan to include all of the rest of the data points from other participants in our analyses.
registration_responses.q23: We don't expect to have any missing data. As the survey is being conducted online in Qualtrics, each question has been built to require a response before the participant can move on to the next question.
registration_responses.q24:
First, plan to investigate framing effects. We will test frame (large number with small unit vs small number with large unit) and Age on discounting in the relevant subset of trials. 

Second, we are curious about the relationship between future time perspective and discounting. We will test if FTP mediates the relationship between age and discounting, and whether or not this relationship is moderated by time delay.

Finally, we plan to investigate whether discount rates correlate with lifetime saving habits, specifically with the amount of money in liquid savings. If this relationship is found to be significant, we will control for wealth in our analyses.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Independent variables: age (between-subjects), discount rate (within-subjects) and time interval (within-subjects)
Dependent variable: proportion of smaller, sooner options chosen
Potential moderators (exploratory analyses): Future Time Perspective, Safety Net and Savings 

Other exploratory analyses: Impact of time label (large number, small unit (e.g. 7 days) vs. small number large unit (e.g. 1 week)
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants: We will collect data from 276 participants (ages 25-84). The sample will be subdivided into six age categories, or bins (i.e: 25-34, 35-44, 45-54, 55-64. 65-74, 75-84). Each bin will have an equal number of participants (i.e: 46), and an equal number of men and women (i.e: 23). Finally, to build a sample that is representative of the US population, we will recruit participants to match the racial diversity described in the most recent US census (i.e: 75% Caucasian, 13% African-American, 5% Asian, etc).
Participants will be recruited with Qualtrics Panels, a service designed to recruit individuals from pre-existing participant pools, based on the criteria of researchers. Qualtrics Panels compensates the participant with Qualtrics points that can ultimately be redeemed for gift cards. We will include healthy participants between the ages of 25-84 and exclude participants with any psychological or neurological health issues as indicated by our online screening survey. 
      

Procedure: The entirety of the study takes places online through a Qualtrics survey. Participants will first answer a brief screening for our inclusion and exclusion criteria (age, gender, and psychological or neurological health issues). Eligible participants will then be consented. This is followed by the demographic questionnaire for age, ethnicity, income, and subjective health. Next, participants will complete the Future Time Perspective (FTP) survey, a 10-item scale to measure their subjective perception of how much time they feel they have left to live. This will be followed by the delay discounting practice round and task, in which participants choose which option they would prefer when presented with a smaller, sooner and a larger, later option.  Finally, they will be presented with the Savings and Safety Net subscale (from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau) to assess their saving habits and financial security across their lifetime . The total survey duration is estimated to be 7-8 minutes.
registration_responses.q16.question:
We are manipulating the time delay between the smaller, sooner option and the larger, later option. There are 4 levels of this variable: days, weeks, months, years. Each level has 3 sub-levels: a low-point, a midpoint, and a high-point. To enable investigations into framing effects, the high-point of one level is equivalent to the low-point of the subsequent level (i.e: 12 months and 1 year).

The delay discounting task itself is comprised of 36 task trials, and 3 catch trials which are used as attention checks. We use a combination of 12 time intervals and 3 hypothetical discount rates to create 36 delay discounting trials. We use the following time intervals: 1 day, 4 days, 7 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 4 weeks, 1 month, 6 months, 12 months, 1 year, 5 year, and 10 years. We use the three different discount rates: k= .1, k= .05, and k=.005. In order to estimate an appropriate future amount, corresponding to the three discount rates and the given time delays, we used the following formula: reward=SV * (1+ k*days). In this formula, SV (subjective value) is the dollar amount of the reward today (set to $10 in every trial), reward is the dollar amount in the future after a given time delay, k is the discount rate, and days is the time delay (given in days). We operationalized a month to be 28 days.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The primary outcome variable is the acceptance rate, or the proportion of sooner options chosen in the delay discounting task. We will measure age (in years) as the continuous covariate, and will measure future time perspective, as measured by the FTP scale (Carstensen and Lang, 1996), as a mediator.
- KS: should I add our demographic questions & savings & safety net questions here too?
registration_responses.q19.question:
H1: We hypothesize that across all ages, we will see greater discounting (or greater proportion of sooner options) with longer time delays.

H2: We hypothesize that this increase in discounting for longer time delays will vary by age. Specifically, we predict that age differences in time preferences will only appear with longer time delays. For shorter time delays (days, weeks, months), there will be no age differences in discount rates. For longer time delays (years), older adults will show greater discounting than younger adults because of uncertainty about their future.

We will test these hypotheses by predicting the proportion of sooner options chosen with two models:

First, we will test a 3 (k-values: 0.1, 0.05, 0.005) by 4 (time: days, weeks, months, years) by Age (25-84 years) ANCOVA. 

H1: Main effect of delay with longer delays (years) having greater acceptance of sooner option.
H2: Age * Delay interaction such that age difference only appear for longer delays (years)

Next, we will convert the categorical predictors above into continuous variables. The three k values will be log-transformed (-1, -1.301, -2.301) to reduce skewness and the twelve time delays will be converted into a common scale: number of days (1 day, 4 days, 7 days, 14 days, 28 days, 30 days, 180 days, 365 days, 1825 days, 1650 days). These two continuous predictors (log(k) and delay in days) will be used in a linear model.


H1: Main effect of number of days such that longer delays ( > 365 days) having greater acceptance of the sooner option.
H2: Age * number of days interaction such that age difference only appear for longer delays (>365 days)

attributes.title: Education and Naloxone Distribution for Overdose Prevention: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews

q1.value: Education and Naloxone Distribution for Overdose Prevention: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews

q3.value: Opioid-related mortality is the leading cause of injury-related death in the United States. Opioid overdoses contributed to more than 45,000 deaths in 2017 alone, surpassing fatalities due to motor vehicles accidents. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that when administered, reverses the effects of opioid overdose, restoring adequate respiration and preventing death among overdose victims. The purpose of this umbrella review is to provide an overview on the effectiveness and impact of programs which provide overdose education and naloxone distribution in community-settings.

q4.value: If overdose education and naloxone distribution programs are effective, the incidence of opioid-related mortality will be reduced in community-settings where implementation is successful.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We will conduct an umbrella review of systematic reviews and meta-analyses to improve access to targeted information. 

A research librarian will search PubMed, Embase (via Ovid), Epistemonikos, and the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews from database inception to November 1st, 2019 using opioid keywords and systematic review filters developed by PubMed and the Canadian Agency for Drugs and Technologies in Health. We will also manually search reference lists of relevant publications. Systematic reviews will be restricted to the English and French language.

Eligible studies will be systematic reviews synthesizing data through qualitative and/or meta-analytical methods. An article will be considered a systematic review if it meets all of the following criteria:

a. Describes the methods, and includes a systematic search strategy, study selection protocol, and inclusion/exclusion criteria.

b. Performs a formal quality assessment of its included primary studies (e.g., Jadad, Cochrane RoB).

c. Reviews of reviews (e.g., umbrella reviews, overviews, meta-reviews) may be included if they searched for and identified additional primary studies not identified within their eligible systematic reviews.

d. We will exclude all abstract and conference proceedings.

Publications must contain outcome data relevant to either 1) the effectiveness of overdose education and naloxone distribution programs or 2) the optimal strategies for the management of opioid overdose with naloxone in out-of-hospital settings. Outcomes of interest include, but are not limited to: rates of opioid-related mortality; rates of bystander naloxone use; changes in bystander overdose knowledge; and changes in bystander overdose response behavior.

a. Primary research may be derived from either randomized or non-randomized studies conducted in human subjects.

b. We will exclude studies reporting on naloxone-based therapies (e.g., buprenorphine-naloxone) for the therapeutic treatment of either opioid addiction or neonatal withdrawal syndrome.

Two reviewers will independently assess the overall quality of eligible systematic reviews with A MeaSurement Tool to Assess systematic Reviews (AMSTAR 2). Designed to assess the quality of systematic reviews of health interventions, reviews will be scored based on seven critical domain: 1) protocol registration; 2) literature search; 3) exclusion criteria; 4) risk of bias assessment; 5) meta-analytical methods; 6) result interpretation; and 7) publication bias. Any discrepancies between reviewer results will be resolved through discussion, or a third reviewer, as necessary.

To provide an overview on the effectiveness of overdose education and naloxone distribution, we will synthesize systematic reviews using a qualitative and analytical approach. We will construct evidence tables with review characteristics and overall quality ratings, and produce summary tables to highlight our principal findings. To consider the potential risk of bias of our conclusions, we will provide a narrative overview of the risk-of-bias of primary studies and visually present the overlap between systematic reviews through the construction of a citation matrix. Summary statements/tables will be produced using a previously modified version of the Royal College of General Practitioners' clinical guidelines.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: The present study was previously submitted to PROSPERO (ID#164824), an International prospective register of systematic review. Due to delays in protocol approval, the protocol is being resubmitted to the Open Science Framework after study completion.

question.value:
Study selection: Two reviewers will independently screen the titles and abstracts of identified articles against our pre-specified eligibility criteria. Publications marked for potential inclusion by either individual will proceed to a secondary full-text assessment, with disagreement resolved by consensus, or when necessary, a third reviewer. Systematic reviews eligible for inclusion will proceed to overall quality assessment. We will record all study selection decisions, with justification, in an Excel workbook.

Data extraction: The data extraction will be conducted similarly. Two reviewers will independently extract data from eligible systematic reviews on the first author, publication year, databases searched, outcomes reported, population, primary studies, and data synthesis. Disagreements between reviewers will be resolved through discussion to consensus, and when necessary, a third reviewer. All data will be recorded in an Excel spreadsheet.

q13.value:
Not applicable. 

All eligible systematic reviews will be included regardless of overall study quality.

question.value:
The primary purpose of this study is to provide an overview on the effectiveness of overdose education and naloxone distribution. We will extract relevant outcomes concerning the implementation of such programs, as reported by eligible systematic reviews.The principal outcomes include, but are not limited to: 1) the safety and efficacy of overdose education and naloxone distribution programs; 2) changes in program participant drug use behavior; and 3) changes in rates of fatal or nonfatal overdose.

We will also extract from eligible systematic reviews their objectives, search strategy, primary studies, examined outcomes, and review conduct setting.
We anticipate to synthesize data qualitatively due to substantial heterogeneity between studies which evaluate overdose education and naloxone distribution programs.

Statistical methods are not applicable. 

We anticipate to synthesize data qualitatively through the construction of evidence tables.

q20.value: The systematic evaluation of overdose education and naloxone distribution programs does not require any additional transformations.

q21.value: We will use the inference criteria reported by systematic reviews when addressing primary studies. We anticipate to principally examine reported confidence intervals which use the standard p<0.05 criteria.

q22.value:
All systematic reviews will be included regardless of overall study quality. 

No checks will be performed to determine data eligibility besides verification that the outcome pertains the efficacy of overdose education and naloxone distribution programs.

q25.value: We will report outcomes as per the Preferred Reporting Items for Overviews of Systematic Reviews (PRIO-SRs) checklist.

Opioid overdoses contributed to more than 45,000 deaths in 2017 alone, surpassing fatalities due to motor vehicles accidents. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that when administered, reverses the effects of opioid overdose, restoring adequate respiration and preventing death among overdose victims. The purpose of this umbrella review is to provide an overview on the effectiveness and impact of programs which provide overdose education and naloxone distribution in community-settings.
registration_responses.q4: If overdose education and naloxone distribution programs are effective, the incidence of opioid-related mortality will be reduced in community-settings where implementation is successful.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q13:
Not applicable. 

All eligible systematic reviews will be included regardless of overall study quality.

registration_responses.q21: We will use the inference criteria reported by systematic reviews when addressing primary studies. We anticipate to principally examine reported confidence intervals which use the standard p<0.05 criteria.
registration_responses.q22:
All systematic reviews will be included regardless of overall study quality. 

No checks will be performed to determine data eligibility besides verification that the outcome pertains the efficacy of overdose education and naloxone distribution programs.

item1.value:
I am trying to replicate the research depicted in the following paper: Tyler, Mary (1977). Why ladies don't swear. Paper presented at the meeting of the Southeast Conference on linguistics (16th, Greensboro, North Carolina, March, 1977). Retrieved from: https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED142091.pdf. 

The paper predicted that "the use of swear words by women elicits more negative perceptions of the speaker than the use of the same words by men". It manipulated the swear words used by the subject of vignettes depicting either an adult suffering from anxiety or a rebellios teenager, as no swearing, mild swearing, or moderate swearing. However, the findings contradicted the predictions: "The mildly swearing woman and the mildly swearing female teenager were perceived as the better adjusted of the various clients."

item8.value: Psychology undergraduate students enrolled in an introductory psychology course

item9.value: Paper-and-pencil surveys (4 fictitional reports presented in a booklet = imaginary vignettes)

item12.value: The experiment will be conducted online using Qualtrics, via the college license of Department of Psychology, College of Human and Health Sciences, Swansea University, UK. The experiment might also be conducted in the lab, where participants will be recruited by the undergraduate students involved in this project; however, the lab sessions will also be administered via the online Qualtrics survey.

item13.value: The experimenters (2 undergraduate students and one staff member, the supervisor) will be blind to participant experimental condition. Participants will be allocated to one variant of the scenarios for the adult client and one variant of the scenarios for the teenager client by Qualtrics: all 6 variants for the adult client and all 6 variants of the teenage client are displayed on the same page each, and Qualtrics will randomly display one.

item14.value: All experimenters (2 undergraduate students and one staff member, the supervisor) are aware of the study hypotheses, but they are not aware of the participant allocation to experimental conditions.

item15.value: A maximum of 360 participants and a minimim of 120 participants, based on a) a relative approximaton of the original sample (however, data for that was very scarce) and b) practical considerations of data collection among an undergraduate psychology sample of participants.

item16.value: This research has six variants for each case study: a non-swearing female (adult + teenager), a swearing female (adult + teenager), a really swearing female (adult + teenager), a non-swearing male (adult + teenager), a swearing male (adult + teenager), and a really swearing male (adult + teenager). As this is a conceptual replication study of Tyler (1997), each participant will receive two case studies, one variant from each of the two cases (adult client and teenage client). In Tyler (1997) original research, they had 20 participants for each variant, therefore based on this we will aim to achieve a minimum of 20 participants and a maximum of 60 participants for each variant (between 120 and 360 participants). They will all be university students.

item24.value:
1. We have increased the number of participants to this survey because I believe that the initial sample size was ridiculously small (n = 20). Hence, the size of the effect I obtain might be bigger, and some effects that were previously non signiificant might become statistically significant now.

2. We have adapted the swear words employed in the original vignettes in order to provide participants with language adapted to 2020. That is:
- in the Swearing Condition, for the Adult Client, we replaced 1 x 'hell' and 1 x 'damn' (original terms) with 1 x 'shit' and 1 x 'damn it'. For the Teenage Client, we replaced 2 x 'hell' and 2 x 'damn' (original terms) with and 2 x 'shit' and 2 x 'bloody';
- in the Really Swearing condition, for the Adult Client, we replaced 1 x 'shit load' and 1 x 'bloody fucking' (original terms) with 1 x 'shit', 1 x 'fucking', and 1 x 'what the fuck'. For the Teenage Client, we replaced 1 x 'fucking', 1 x 'shit load', 1 x 'what the fuck', and 1 x 'shitty' (original terms) with 2 x 'fucking', 1 x 'fuck all', 1 x 'what the fuck', 1 x 'bloody', and 1 x 'shitty'.

3. We have replaced the measure of the client's 'promiscuity' with a measure of the client's 'immorality', in an attempt to use a more modern term. The response scale remained the same except for the label (1 = very immoral; 5 = very moral).

4. We included two additional measures, to the original measures: 
A) The client’s authenticity (…how genuine is this client?, from 1 = very little genuine to 5 = very genuine); and B) The client’s subjective SES (socio-economic status) measured with the MacArthur Scale of subjective SES (original by Goodman, Adler, Kawachi, Frazier, Huang & Colditz, 2001). Participants mark an X next to one of 10 rungs on a ladder to indicate their own social class rank relative to comparison individuals. Each rung of the ladder was given a number between 1 and 10, with higher numbers indicating higher placement on the ladder (Kraus, Piff & Keltner, 2009).

item25.value:
Regarding point 1: We do not see what steps we need to take in order to test whether the differences listed in the previous question will influence the outcome of our replication attempt, because increasing the sample size from a ridiculous previous number is not a shortcoming/limitation we need to account for. 

Regarding point 2: We do not foresee why the new swear words would have less potential for producing the predicted findings than the original swear words. The only reason we replaced the original terms with some new ones is in order to have a more modern-parlance text and, thus, incresase the credibility of the vignettes. 

Regarding point 3: N/A

Regarding point 4: N/A - these variables have not been tested before in such a design.

item26.value: We do not use any manipulation checks. We plan to perform statistical analyses on all participants’ data, except for data from participants who indicated that they understood specific hypotheses of this study at the suspicion probe stage. If, however, participants only provide generic hints about what the hypotheses could, should, or would be, we will not discard their data.

item28.value: one that produced similar findings to the effects of swearing on judgments of anger and self-control (for the adult client) and judgments of anger, self-control, immorality and overall level of functioning (for the teenage client).

registration_responses.item24:
1. We have increased the number of participants to this survey because I believe that the initial sample size was ridiculously small (n = 20). Hence, the size of the effect I obtain might be bigger, and some effects that were previously non signiificant might become statistically significant now.

2. We have adapted the swear words employed in the original vignettes in order to provide participants with language adapted to 2020. That is:
- in the Swearing Condition, for the Adult Client, we replaced 1 x 'hell' and 1 x 'damn' (original terms) with 1 x 'shit' and 1 x 'damn it'. For the Teenage Client, we replaced 2 x 'hell' and 2 x 'damn' (original terms) with and 2 x 'shit' and 2 x 'bloody';
- in the Really Swearing condition, for the Adult Client, we replaced 1 x 'shit load' and 1 x 'bloody fucking' (original terms) with 1 x 'shit', 1 x 'fucking', and 1 x 'what the fuck'. For the Teenage Client, we replaced 1 x 'fucking', 1 x 'shit load', 1 x 'what the fuck', and 1 x 'shitty' (original terms) with 2 x 'fucking', 1 x 'fuck all', 1 x 'what the fuck', 1 x 'bloody', and 1 x 'shitty'.

3. We have replaced the measure of the client's 'promiscuity' with a measure of the client's 'immorality', in an attempt to use a more modern term. The response scale remained the same except for the label (1 = very immoral; 5 = very moral).

4. We included two additional measures, to the original measures: 
A) The client’s authenticity (…how genuine is this client?, from 1 = very little genuine to 5 = very genuine); and B) The client’s subjective SES (socio-economic status) measured with the MacArthur Scale of subjective SES (original by Goodman, Adler, Kawachi, Frazier, Huang & Colditz, 2001). Participants mark an X next to one of 10 rungs on a ladder to indicate their own social class rank relative to comparison individuals. Each rung of the ladder was given a number between 1 and 10, with higher numbers indicating higher placement on the ladder (Kraus, Piff & Keltner, 2009).
registration_responses.item25:
Regarding point 1: We do not see what steps we need to take in order to test whether the differences listed in the previous question will influence the outcome of our replication attempt, because increasing the sample size from a ridiculous previous number is not a shortcoming/limitation we need to account for. 

Regarding point 2: We do not foresee why the new swear words would have less potential for producing the predicted findings than the original swear words. The only reason we replaced the original terms with some new ones is in order to have a more modern-parlance text and, thus, incresase the credibility of the vignettes. 

Regarding point 3: N/A

Regarding point 4: N/A - these variables have not been tested before in such a design.
registration_responses.item26: We do not use any manipulation checks. We plan to perform statistical analyses on all participants’ data, except for data from participants who indicated that they understood specific hypotheses of this study at the suspicion probe stage. If, however, participants only provide generic hints about what the hypotheses could, should, or would be, we will not discard their data.
registration_responses.item28: one that produced similar findings to the effects of swearing on judgments of anger and self-control (for the adult client) and judgments of anger, self-control, immorality and overall level of functioning (for the teenage client).
